page.title: 08UNDERTAKER, WHITTON
page.content: A.HOSKINS & SON, THE CARPENTER'S SHOP, WHITTON, FUNERAL DIRECTOR, Records show that a John Hoskins was a funeral director in 1890. The cost of a funeral then was Â£8..6..6 (now it costs several hundred pounds, according to requirements). The business has been handed down from father to son and Reg, the present proprietor, continues to make coffins much as they were in his grandfather's day,mostly from oak with elm bottoms. When a person dies they are brought to the Chapel of Rest where there is a cold room. Each coffin is made for the individual and can have brass or nickel handles etc.(wooden if a cremation is desired). The inside is lined with white material with a white satin frill.A shroud of white,pink or blue satin is put on the deceased. Relatives come and view if they wish.
